title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with coverage options including individual, family, and self plus one plans. Participation is voluntary, with about 85% of employees and 90% of retirees enrolled. Plans fall into fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs) categories, with shared premiums between the government and individuals. All plans cover basic services like hospital and physician care, with varying cost sharing through deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established parameters for eligibility, coverage election, types of health plans, and government's share of premiums for federal employees. Prior to FEHBA, federal employees had limited options for health insurance, with some purchasing coverage voluntarily or through union plans. President Truman's Commission recommended federal health insurance in 1951, leading to the creation of FEHBA in 1959. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established program expenses funding, OPM's role, and insurer contracting authority. FEHBA has been amended multiple times, with changes in premium cost-sharing, eligibility, and benefits expansion. Congress plays a role in modifying FEHB, with policymakers and researchers showing interest in the program. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHB) has been a model for both private and public health insurance programs. It allows enrollees to choose from competing insurers with minimal intervention, promoting cost-conscious choices and controlling overall costs. Researchers have explored exporting aspects of FEHB to other programs like Medicare, expanding access to non-federal individuals, and creating new programs based on FEHB. Some policymakers have introduced legislation to expand FEHB eligibility or create new programs. Lessons from FEHB have also been considered for state-level health insurance exchanges. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHB) has been influential in shaping health insurance exchanges. Lessons learned from FEHB have been considered for the Affordable Care Act. Congressional policymakers play a role in ensuring FEHB's viability and sustainability. Congress has financial interest in FEHB and the authority to make changes to the program. The report aims to explain FEHB's evolution and Congress's past interactions with the program. The government's share of FEHB premiums has increased over the years, with Congress enacting laws that place conditions on the use of federal funds for the program. For example, in 1983, a law prohibited using federal funds for abortions except in cases of danger to the woman's life. This provision has been renewed with some changes annually, except in 1994 and 1995. Subsequent appropriations bills have included this provision each year. The government's share of FEHB premiums has increased over the years, with Congress enacting laws that place conditions on the use of federal funds for the program. In 1971, the "big six" formula was created, setting the government's share at 40% of the simple average of the big six premiums, which increased to 50% in 1974. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 introduced the current formula where the government contributes 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans, not exceeding 75% of any one plan's premium. Eligible participants include current federal employees, retirees, and their family members. Since its enactment, eligibility for the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act (FEHBA) has been extended to more categories of federal employees, retirees, and their family members. In 1978, part-time employees became eligible, followed by certain temporary workers in 1988. Temporary continuation of coverage (TCC) was also authorized in 1988, allowing separated employees to continue FEHB coverage for up to 18 months. TCC enrollees must pay the full premium and a 2% administrative fee. Children aging out of their parents' plans may have coverage for up to 36 months. Initially established five years before Medicare, there was little interaction between the programs in the early years. In 1982, Congress passed the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (P.L. 97-248), allowing federal workers to be eligible for Medicare based on their federal employment. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (P.L. 86-382) established the FEHB program for federal employees and retirees, outlining eligibility, benefits, premiums, and OPM's role. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 established the FEHB program for federal employees and retirees. Retirees who retired after July 1, 1960, with at least 12 years of service or for a disability were eligible, along with their family members. OPM could contract or approve different types of health benefit plans to participate in FEHB. The FEHB program was established in 1959 for federal employees and retirees, including those who retired after July 1, 1960. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans depended on the type of plan and enrollee, with specific biweekly government shares for different coverage types. The FEHB program, established in 1959, provided government shares of premiums for federal employees and retirees based on plan type and enrollee. The Postal Employees Salary Increase Act of 1960 and To Amend the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 expanded coverage and extended deadlines for applications from qualified employee organizations. P.L. 88-284, passed on March 17, 1964, removed the requirement for employee organizations to offer health care benefits before applying for FEHB. It expanded coverage to include employees with work-related injuries, foster children, and unmarried children up to age 21. The act also allowed retirees to continue FEHB coverage if enrolled by December 31, 1964. OPM was given authority to terminate contracts with carriers not meeting enrollment requirements. Premium shares were made equal for all enrollees, regardless of gender. The act changed the government's share of premiums for employee organization plans and comprehensive medical plans, making the share of the premium the same for all enrollees, regardless of gender. P.L. 88-531 authorized FEHB coverage for certain United States commissioners and their dependents if the Civil Service Retirement Act applies to the commissioners. P.L. 88-631, P.L. 89-379, and P.L. 89-504 extended FEHB coverage to teachers in DC, congressional employees with fellowships, and amended FEHB to change government share of premiums and extend coverage for dependent children. FEHB coverage was extended to dependent children up to age 22. National Guard technicians became eligible for FEHB coverage in 1969. Full-time United States magistrates and their assistants were granted FEHB coverage in 1968. Federal employees were given the option to continue FEHB during transfer to international organizations in 1969. Government contribution to health benefits insurance was adjusted in 1970 to reflect medical price inflation. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program underwent changes in the 1970s, including adjustments to the government's contribution to reflect medical price inflation. The "big six" formula was established in 1971, determining the government's share at 40% of the average of six benefit plans. Additionally, FEHB coverage was extended to noncitizen employees in the Panama Canal Zone and family members of deceased employees with less than five years of service. In the 1970s, changes were made to the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program. P.L. 93-160 extended FEHB coverage to eligible U.S. nationals employed by the federal government outside the U.S. and Panama Canal Zone. P.L. 93-246 increased the government's share of the FEHB plan premium from 40% to 50% of the average of the big six premiums in 1974. The government's share of FEHB plan premiums was increased to 60% of the big six average premiums in 1975, with a maximum limit of 75%. Health insurance plans in FEHB had to comply with OPM decisions on health benefits disputes. P.L. 93-363 allowed direct access to clinical psychologists and optometrists without referral, with payment for services provided. The amendments in P.L. 94-310 allowed the government's share of health plan premiums for retirees to be available until expended. P.L. 94-342 restored eligibility for health benefits coverage to surviving spouses whose annuities were restored after termination due to remarriage. P.L. 95-368 established uniformity in benefits and coverage under FEHB by preempting certain state and local laws inconsistent with FEHB contracts. The Federal Employees Part-Time Career Employment Act of 1978 (P.L. 95-437) allowed part-time career employees and their dependents to access FEHB coverage. It defined part-time career employment as consisting of a 16 to 32-hour work week, excluding temporary or intermittent employment. The act also made changes to the appeals process for employee organizations seeking to sponsor a health benefit plan. P.L. 95-583 reduced the required years of service for FEHB coverage in retirement from 12 to 5 years. P.L. 96-54 redefined employee for FEHB coverage purposes, excluding United States commissioners. P.L. 96-70 redefined employee eligibility for FEHB coverage. P.L. 96-70 redefined employee eligibility for FEHB coverage, excluding non-citizens stationed outside the US. P.L. 96-179 amended survivor benefits and dependency requirements for FEHB coverage. P.L. 97-248 required federal employees to pay Medicare tax starting January 1, 1983. The Insurance tax act enabled federal employees to count their federal employment towards entitlement for premium-free benefits under Medicare Part A. It also made Medicare payments secondary for employees aged 65 to 69 covered under certain employer group health plans. P.L. 97-346 required OPM to adjust government contributions for health plan premiums based on employee organizations. The government paid the difference into contingency reserves of FEHB plans in 1983. P.L. 98-151 prohibited funds from being used for abortions in FEHB plans, except in cases where the woman's life is endangered. P.L. 98-615 extended FEHB coverage to former spouses of federal employees, who must pay both the employee's and government's share of the premium. P.L. 99-53 authorized additional employee organization plans in FEHB if applied within 90 days of enactment. It allowed certain disability annuitants to enroll in an FEHB plan if previously enrolled. P.L. 99-251 introduced mixed model prepayment plans in FEHB and eliminated certain requirements. P.L. 99-251 expanded FEHB contracting authority to include health practitioners like nurse midwives and chiropractors, as well as clinical social workers. It also emphasized the importance of adequate treatment for mental illness, alcoholism, and drug addiction for FEHB enrollees. Additionally, the act allowed OPM to waive the five-year service requirement for FEHB coverage in retirement under exceptional circumstances and mandated a study on the adequacy of FEHB information materials. The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 (P.L. 99-272) required OPM to set minimum financial reserves for health plan carriers. Any excess reserves were to be returned to the Employees Health Benefits Fund. Starting October 1, 1986, USPS had to pay the government's share of health plan premiums for retired postal employees. The act also made Medicare payments secondary for services provided to employees aged 70 and older. The Federal Employees' Retirement System Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-335) extended FEHB eligibility to certain individuals. The Federal Employees' Retirement System Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-335) extended FEHB eligibility to individuals first employed by the government of the District of Columbia before October 1, 1987. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1987 (P.L. 99-569) provided health benefits for certain former spouses of CIA employees. The Joint Resolution Making Further Continuing Appropriations for the Fiscal Year 1988 (P.L. 100-202) added qualified clinical social workers to non-physician providers eligible for FEHB coverage. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987 (P.L. 100-203) specified USPS contributions to the Employee Health Benefits Fund for certain retirees. The Foreign Relations Authorization Act, Fiscal Years 1988 and 1989 (P.L. 100-204) provided FEHB coverage for certain former spouses of employees. The Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-360) included provisions affecting FEHB, later repealed by the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Repeal Act of 1989 (P.L. 101-234). It would have required OPM to reduce rates for Medicare-eligible retirees in FEHB and specified the reduction based on estimated medical costs. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Amendments Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-654) required OPM to report to Congress on changes needed for health benefit plans for Medicare-eligible individuals and to adopt NAIC standards for Medicare supplemental plans under FEHB. It also allowed OPM to impose sanctions on providers convicted of illegal activities related to healthcare. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act Amendments of 1988 (P.L. 100-679) provided provisions for certain employees and directed OPM to offer health benefits coverage to temporary federal employees with one year of continuous service. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989 (P.L. 101-239) required the USPS to pay the government's share of FEHB premiums for survivors of postal employees. This act adjusted the big six formula for calculating the government's share of FEHB plans in response to Aetna's withdrawal from the program. If comprehensive reform legislation is enacted that amends FEHB financing provisions, the provisions of this act would not apply. The Foreign Relations Authorization Act, Fiscal Years 1990 and 1991 (P.L. 101-246) authorized FEHB coverage for certain former spouses of Foreign Service employees. Additionally, the To Amend Title 5, United States Code (P.L. 101-303) allowed federal retirees to pay health benefits premiums through direct payments if their annuity was insufficient. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 (P.L. 101-508) included various FEHB-related reforms such as implementing hospitalization cost-containment measures, improving cash management, exempting FEHB plans from state premium taxes, and extending the restructured big six formula. It also required coordination between FEHB and Medicare, applying Medicare payment limits to certain services for retired FEHB enrollees aged 65 and older. The Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act of 1991 (P.L. 101-513) provided FEHB benefits to U.S. hostages in Iraq, Kuwait, and Lebanon, and their family members, for 12 months after release. The act also required the USPS to pay the government's share of FEHB premiums for annuitants retiring from USPS employment after July 1, 1971. P.L. 101-530, P.L. 102-88, and P.L. 102-90 provided various amendments related to FEHB benefits for National Guard technicians, former spouses of CIA employees, and Senate Employee Child Care Center employees. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1993 (P.L. 102-393) prohibited changes to FEHB affecting Medicare beneficiaries. OPM was restricted from requiring retired FEHB enrollees eligible for Medicare to pay out-of-pocket differences with nonparticipating Medicare providers. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993 (P.L. 102-484) allowed continuation of FEHB benefits for involuntary separation from the Department of Defense. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (P.L. 103-66) directed the Secretary of Defense to review FEHB for efficiency. It also limited payments for coverage to the employee's share of premiums and required the last employing agency to cover the rest. Additionally, the act required most FEHB plans to apply Medicare Part B limitations on payments for physician services to retired FEHB enrollees aged 65 or older who do not participate in Medicare Part B. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (P.L. 103-66) directed the Secretary of Defense to review FEHB for efficiency and limited payments for coverage. It also required most FEHB plans to apply Medicare Part B limitations on payments for physician services to retired FEHB enrollees aged 65 or older who do not participate in Medicare Part B. In addition, the Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1994 (P.L. 103-123) extended and modified the restructured big six formula for plan years 1990 through 1998. The FEGLI Living Benefits Act, 1994 (P.L. 103-409) allowed individuals covered under health benefit plans administered by specific offices to access living benefits. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 directed the Secretary of Defense to review FEHB for efficiency and limited payments for coverage. It also required most FEHB plans to apply Medicare Part B limitations on payments for physician services to retired FEHB enrollees aged 65 or older who do not participate in Medicare Part B. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1994 extended and modified the restructured big six formula for plan years 1990 through 1998. The FEGLI Living Benefits Act, 1994 allowed individuals covered under specific health benefit plans to access living benefits. The Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996 allowed individuals covered under health benefit plans administered by the Farm Credit Administration to enroll in an FEHB plan for coverage effective on and after September 30, 1995. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1996 reinstated the provision prohibiting appropriated funds from being available to pay for an abortion or for the administrative expenses of any health plan under FEHB that provides benefits or coverage for abortions. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1996 (P.L. 104-106) changed the Transitional Continuation of Coverage (TCC) for certain individuals. It allowed those who voluntarily separate from surplus positions in the Department of Defense or Department of Energy to continue FEHB coverage by paying only the employee's share of premiums. The Omnibus Consolidated Appropriations Act, 1997 (P.L. 104-208) required OPM to create regulations for surviving children to enroll in FEHB plans if their survivor annuity was terminated due to marriage but later restored. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (P.L. 105-33) modified the formula for determining the government's share of FEHB premiums, requiring OPM to calculate the weighted average premium of all plans by October 1st each year. The biweekly government share of an FEHB plan for an employee or retiree is set at 72% of the weighted average premium. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (P.L. 105-33) set the government's share of FEHB premiums at 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans. P.L. 105-33 also mandated that individuals enrolled in FEHB cannot enroll in a Medicare Medical Savings Account plan until OPM certifies to HHS. Additionally, P.L. 105-261 directed the Secretary of Defense to conduct a demonstration project allowing certain individuals eligible for Department of Defense health benefits to enroll in FEHB plans voluntarily. The Federal Employees Health Care Protection Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-266) made administrative changes to FEHB, including debarring fraudulent health care providers and modifying the definition of a carrier. It also allowed government-wide plans in FEHB to be underwritten by affiliates licensed in each state. The act required reports on project costs and effectiveness, and the feasibility of making the program permanent. The Federal Employees Health Care Protection Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-266) established rules for FEHB plans, including provisions that supersede state or local laws related to health insurance. It encouraged carriers to obtain discounts from healthcare providers and clarified that plans can provide direct access to licensed providers not specified in statute. The District of Columbia Courts and Justice Technical Corrections Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-274) and the Omnibus Consolidated and Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act, 1999 (P.L. 105-277) expanded eligibility for FEHB plans and required coverage of contraceptives, respectively. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000 (P.L. 106-65) required the Secretary of Defense to compare health care coverage under TRICARE and FEHB, including cost-sharing requirements and covered benefits. The Veterans Millennium Health Care and Benefits Act (P.L. 106-117) changed coverage under FEHB for certain individuals, allowing them to continue coverage and pay only the employee's share of premiums. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Children's Equity Act of 2000 (P.L. 106-394) mandates that employees who are required to provide health insurance coverage for a dependent child must do so under FEHB if they cannot provide documentation of other coverage. If the employee is no longer enrolled in FEHB, the agency must enroll them in a family plan with lower coverage. Employees with individual coverage can switch to family coverage, and if they do not, the agency will change their enrollment to family coverage. The National Defense Authorization Act, Fiscal Year 2001 (P.L. 106-398) directed a study comparing Department of Defense health programs with Medicare and FEHB plans for therapies. The District of Columbia Appropriations Act, 2001 (P.L. 106-522) allowed certain DC employees to be treated as federal employees for FEHB eligibility. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2002 (P.L. 107-107) authorized agencies to pay premiums for reservists on active duty. The State Justice Institute Reauthorization Act of 2004 (P.L. 108-372) extended FEHB coverage to State Justice Institute employees. P.L. 107-304 allowed beneficiaries of an Overseas Private Investment Corporation health plan to obtain FEHB coverage. The Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 extended FEHB coverage to federal employees in the reserve component of the Armed Forces called to active duty for more than 30 days. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 authorized the Director of the CIA to protect intelligence operations and sources. The Director of the CIA can establish a nonofficial cover employee health insurance program for designated employees and their families. Designated employees in this program cannot participate in FEHB simultaneously but can switch to FEHB coverage at any time. Legislation in 2004 and 2007 expanded health insurance options under FEHB for specific groups of individuals. The International Park Commission is eligible for health insurance under FEHB. P.L. 110-279 authorized continued federal benefits for certain Senate restaurant employees after operations are contracted out. P.L. 110-422 specified TCC requirements under FEHB for NASA employees due to various circumstances. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) requires NASA to pay the remaining share of the premium for employees receiving TCC under FEHB. FEHB plans must comply with ACA provisions, with OPM providing guidance on implementation. The ACA allows adult children up to age 26 to remain on their parents' health insurance. The ACA extended dependent coverage to age 26, allowing adult children to stay on their parent's health insurance plan. Preventive care services must be offered with no out-of-pocket costs, with waivers for in-network providers. Plans must provide TCC for three years when a child ages out at 26, and disabled children can remain dependents indefinitely if disabled before 26. The ACA required plans to provide a summary of benefits and coverage (SBC) and a glossary of terms to applicants and enrollees. Plans were prohibited from establishing lifetime limits on certain health benefits and had to eliminate annual limits by 2014. FEHB plans were expected to allow individuals to participate in approved clinical trials. The ACA required FEHB plans to comply with coverage requirements for clinical trials starting in 2013 and prohibited preexisting condition exclusions in 2014. Another requirement involved reporting a medical loss ratio and issuing rebates if the ratio of premium revenue spent on claims and health quality costs is less than 85%. Rebates are deposited into the health plan's contingency reserve. The ACA modified qualified medical expenses for tax-advantaged accounts, excluding OTC medicines unless prescribed. It raised penalties for nonqualified HSA withdrawals and lowered HCFSA contributions. Eligible Indian tribes can purchase FEHB for tribal employees. The ACA required tribes to pay the government's share of employee health insurance premiums. It imposed administrative requirements on employers, including reporting coverage costs on W-2 forms. Insurers and employers had to report coverage details to the Secretary of HHS. Only ACA-created health plans or exchange-offered plans are available to Members of Congress and certain staff. Beginning January 1, 2014, Members and designated congressional staff could no longer purchase FEHB plans as active employees but could enroll in health plans offered through a SHOP exchange with an employer contribution. Those eligible for retirement could enroll in an FEHB plan upon retirement. The ACA imposed fees on health insurance plans, including an annual fee based on market share and a PCORI fee on insurers. A 40% excise tax on health insurers and plan administrators will be imposed starting in 2018. Starting in 2018, a 40% excise tax will be imposed on health insurers and plan administrators for coverage exceeding certain thresholds. This includes employer and employee premium payments for health insurance, dental and vision coverage premiums, and payments towards health-related accounts. The thresholds are $10,200 for single coverage and $27,500 for family coverage, indexed to inflation. Any amount exceeding these thresholds will be subject to the tax. Additionally, the ACA requires the Director of OPM to offer at least two multistate plans through each exchange in each state. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013 (P.L. 113-67) allows FEHB enrollees to choose "self plus one" coverage. The government will determine the premium share for self plus one based on the weighted average premium of all FEHB plans. The Director of OPM can establish separate units for MSP administration without reducing resources for FEHB. FEHB plans are not required to offer MSPs. OPM will determine the weighted average premium for self plus one coverage based on an actuarial analysis.
